list_page_teaser: The women of Deadwood share a preference for making emotional decisions, which shows up as Red in their spiritual portraits.  Click to see the images!
description_html:
Women are often seen as being more emotional than men, and spiritual portraits on this page show that the women of Deadwood certainly conform to that stereotype.

  • Alma Garret's image shows she is extremely decisive.
  • Trixie's image shows she is passionate and very open to new experiences.
  • Calamity Jane Canary's image shows she is passionate and very open to new experiences.
  • Joanie Stubbs' image shows she is very passionate and more pragmatic than idealistic.

Women's options in 19th-century Deadwood were extremely limited. These spiritual portraits show that the women in the leading roles all share compassion, and that those with power could afford to be more decisive than those who had less.
story_html:
Writing really good stories explaining how the spiritual portraits of fictional characters reflect the characters' personalities is time-consuming. I'd rather just turn out images and let people figure them out on their own.

The Deadwood Experiment

In building a site like this, the following questions come to mind:

  1. Are the explanatory stories provided necessary or even helpful?
  2. Can fans of a show with an ensemble cast appreciate the images — and see the relationships between the characters — without explanatory stories?
  3. Would it be better — maybe in some cases, at least — to write a single article about all of the portraits in a single show, and post it on social media? This could certainly be easier and might even be more informative than writing a separate story for each character.

For the time being, these spiritual portraits of Deadwood characters are presented without stories. If you are familiar with the show and know a bit about Jungian Psychological Types, you should be able to see how the characters with similar temperaments have similar portraits.

Keep Up-to-Date!

If you're interested in learning when we write new stories and post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.title: Alma Garret
image_list.subtitle_html: Wealthy Widow, Recovering Drug Addict, and Banker
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Alma Garret is extremely decisive, preferring to make emotional (Red) decisions.  As a rich widow, this is certainly her prerogative.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Alma Garret's dominant personality trait, her extremely realistic outlook.  In Introverts, the dominant trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long horizontal line to represent this.  Alma demonstrates/exhibits this trait when she succumbs to the sensual pleasures provided by laudanum, despite knowing how bad it is for her.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Alma Garret's auxiliary personality trait, her passion.  In Introverts, the auxiliary trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a vertical line to represent this, because it is more evident than the dominant function.  Alma demonstrates this trait when she follows her passion and has an affair with Seth Bullock, despite the fact that he is already married.

image_list.title: Trixie
image_list.subtitle_html: Prostitute at the Gem, Hardware Store Employee, and Bank Teller,
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Trixie is extremely perceptive (Yellow) and open to new experiences - hence the multiple jobs - with only a slight preference for making emotional (Red) rather than logical decisions.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Trixie's dominant personality trait, her openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Trixie demonstrates this trait in the way she is willing to try out a number of different occupations in various businesses in the town.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Trixie's auxiliary personality trait, her warmth and passion.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Trixie demonstrates this preference in the way she obviously continues to have deep feelings for Al even when she has stopped working for him and moved on to other opportunities for employment.

image_list.title: 'Calamity' Jane Canary
image_list.subtitle_html: Former Scout for George Armstrong Custer and Alcoholic
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: 'Calamity' Jane Canary is extremely perceptive (Yellow and Blue), making her quite indecisive.  This is actually understandable, given her extreme alcoholism.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Jane's dominant personality trait, her realism.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Jane demonstrates this trait in the way she is always in the current moment, and rarely talks about the past or the future.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Jane's auxiliary personality trait, her amiability and friendliness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Jane demonstrates this trait in the deep feelings she has for her friends such as Wild Bill Hickock, Charlie Utter, and Joanie Stubbs.

image_list.title: Joanie Stubbs
image_list.subtitle_html: Former Madame at the Bella Union Saloon
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Joanie Stubbs shows a very strong preference for making emotional decisions (Red), but can be indecisive at times (Yellow and Blue).  Sometimes her emotions run so strongly that even she has difficulty understanding them - which may be due to the abuse she suffered when she was younger.  Click on the image to see a full-size version!
image_list.explain_dom: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Joanie's dominant personality trait her strong preference for passion and being friendly.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Joanie demonstrates this trait in the way her emotions are so strong that sometimes - especially during times of stress - she has difficulty in dealing with and even just expressing them.
image_list.explain_aux: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Joanie's auxiliary personality trait, her realistic outlook.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Joanie demonstrates this trait in her decision to be a madame rather than try to put her father's abuse behind her and find a more 'respectable' way to survive.
